The word 太 (tài) means 'too' or 'extremely', and 了 (le) is a change of state particle to indicate the condition has reached the point that it is considered extreme. It is often used as a negative criticism, but can also be used positively.

examples.cn: 你的手机太旧了，你应该换一个新的。
examples.pinyin: Nǐ de shǒujī tài jiù le, nǐ yīnggāi huàn yīgè xīn de.
examples.en: Your phone is too old, you should get a new one.

examples.cn: 这道菜太辣了，我吃不下。
examples.pinyin: Zhè dào cài tài là le, wǒ chī bù xià.
examples.en: This dish is too spicy, I can't eat it.

examples.cn: 他太高了，我都看不到他的脸。
examples.pinyin: Tā tài gāo le, wǒ dū kàn bú dào tā de liǎn.
examples.en: He is too tall, I can't even see his face.

examples.cn: 这部电影太好看了，我已经看了三遍。
examples.pinyin: Zhè bù diànyǐng tài hǎokàn le, wǒ yǐjīng kànle sān biàn.
examples.en: This movie is so good, I've already watched it three times.

title: ...的时候 (...de shíhòu) - When...
short_explanation: Used to refer to a specific point or period of time, equivalent to 'when' in English.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese phrase '...的时候 (...de shíhòu)' is utilized to reference to a specific point in time or a period of time when an event occurs. It essentially translates to 'when' in English. This phrase is frequently used to describe a specific time or period when an action takes place, or to express conditional situations if certain conditions are met.
formation: Subject + Verb +的时候 + Rest of the sentence

examples.cn: 我小时候，爸爸经常带我去公园玩。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ xiǎoshíhòu, bàba jīngcháng dài wǒ qù gōngyuán wán.
examples.en: When I was little, my dad used to take me to the park to play.

examples.cn: 你学习的时候，喜欢听音乐吗？
examples.pinyin: Nǐ xuéxí de shíhòu, xǐhuān tīng yīnyuè ma?
examples.en: Do you like to listen to music when you study?

examples.cn: 她做饭的时候，喜欢看电视。
examples.pinyin: Tā zuò fàn de shíhòu, xǐhuān kàn diànshì.
examples.en: She likes to watch TV when she cooks.

examples.cn: 我累的时候，我通常会去跑步放松一下。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ lèi de shíhòu, wǒ tōngcháng huì qù pǎobù fàngsōng yīxià.
examples.en: When I feel tired, I usually go for a run to relax.

title: 从...到... (cóng...dào...) - From... to...
short_explanation: This is used to express range, from one point to another.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese phrase '从...到...' (cóng...dào...) is used to indicate a range or span from one end to another. This can be used to describe time, place, condition or degree etc. The structure literally translates to 'from... to...' in English.
formation: 从 + Point A + 到 + Point B

examples.cn: 我每天从早到晚都在工作。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ měitiān cóng zǎo dào wǎn dōu zài gōngzuò.
examples.en: I work from morning to night every day.

examples.cn: 从北京到上海大约需要五个小时的飞行时间。
examples.pinyin: Cóng Běijīng dào Shànghǎi dàyuē xūyào wǔ gè xiǎoshí de fēixíng shíjiān.
examples.en: It takes about five hours to fly from Beijing to Shanghai.

examples.cn: 这个展览从明天开始到下个星期五结束。
examples.pinyin: Zhège zhǎnlǎn cóng míngtiān kāishǐ dào xià gè xīngqī wǔ jiéshù.
examples.en: This exhibition runs from tomorrow until next Friday.

examples.cn: 他的情绪从愤怒到悲伤。
examples.pinyin: Tā de qíngxù cóng fènnù dào bēishāng.
examples.en: His mood went from angry to sad.

title: 跟...一样 (gēn... yíyàng) - The same as...
short_explanation: Used to describe similarities between two things or people.
long_explanation: The Chinese expression '跟...一样 (gēn... yíyàng)' is a comparative structure used to highlight the similarities between two subjects. It corresponds to 'the same as...' in English. This structure is commonly applied to show similarity in appearance, characteristics, or behavior.
formation: Subject + 跟 + Object + 一样 + Verb/Adjective

examples.cn: 他的中文跟老师一样好。
examples.pinyin: Tā de Zhōngwén gēn lǎoshī yíyàng hǎo.
examples.en: His Chinese is as good as the teacher's.

examples.cn: 这本书跟那本书一样精彩。
examples.pinyin: Zhè běn shū gēn nà běn shū yíyàng jīngcǎi.
examples.en: This book is as exciting as that one.

examples.cn: 他的工作跟我的一样辛苦。
examples.pinyin: Tā de gōngzuò gēn wǒ de yíyàng xīnkǔ.
examples.en: His job is as hard as mine.

examples.cn: 我妹妹跟我一样喜欢听音乐。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ mèimei gēn wǒ yíyàng xǐhuan tīng yīnyuè.
examples.en: My sister likes listening to music just as I do.

title: 比 (bǐ) - Compare/Than
short_explanation: Used to compare two things or people.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese character '比 (bǐ)' is used to compare two things, people, or situations, similar to the English word 'than' in comparison sentences. It forms a bridge between two items being compared, allowing us to express which one is superior in some way.

examples.cn: 我比你高。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ bǐ nǐ gāo.
examples.en: I am taller than you.

examples.cn: 这本书比那本书有趣。
examples.pinyin: Zhè běn shū bǐ nà běn shū yǒuqù.
examples.en: This book is more interesting than that book.

examples.cn: 他的汉语比我的汉语好。
examples.pinyin: Tā de Hànyǔ bǐ wǒ de Hànyǔ hǎo.
examples.en: His Chinese is better than my Chinese.

examples.cn: 今天比昨天冷。
examples.pinyin: Jīntiān bǐ zuótiān lěng.
examples.en: Today is colder than yesterday.

title: 还是 (háishì) - Or (in questions)
short_explanation: Used to connect two alternatives in a question.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese phrase '还是 (háishì)' is typically used to present a choice between two or more options within a question. It is equivalent to the use of 'or' in English when asking a question. This is often used to inquire about preferences or to suggest different possibilities.

examples.cn: 你想喝茶还是咖啡？
examples.pinyin: Nǐ xiǎng hē chá háishì kāfēi?
examples.en: Do you want to drink tea or coffee?

examples.cn: 你更喜欢看电影还是看电视剧？
examples.pinyin: Nǐ gēng xǐhuān kàn diànyǐng háishì kàn diànshìjù?
examples.en: Do you prefer watching movies or watching TV shows?

examples.cn: 我们现在去公园还是等下午去？
examples.pinyin: Wǒmen xiànzài qù gōngyuán háishì děng xiàwǔ qù?
examples.en: Should we go to the park now or wait until this afternoon?

examples.cn: 我应该买这个红色的还是蓝色的？
examples.pinyin: Wǒ yīnggāi mǎi zhège hóngsè de háishì lán sè de?
examples.en: Should I buy this red one or the blue one?

title: 因为...所以... (yīnwèi... suǒyǐ...) - Because... Therefore/So...
short_explanation: Used to express a cause and effect relationship.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese structure '因为...所以...' is used to link two clauses in a cause-effect relationship. It is equivalent to the English 'because... therefore/so...'. The cause is stated after '因为' and the resulting effect or outcome is placed after '所以'.
formation: 因为 + Cause, 所以 + Effect.

examples.cn: 因为昨天下雨，所以我们今天不能去公园。
examples.pinyin: Yīnwèi zuótiān xià yǔ, suǒyǐ wǒmen jīntiān bù néng qù gōngyuán.
examples.en: Because it rained yesterday, therefore we cannot go to the park today.

examples.cn: 因为我有一次坏的经验，所以我不愿意再试。
examples.pinyin: Yīnwèi wǒ yǒu yīcì huài de jīngyàn, suǒyǐ wǒ bù yuànyì zàishì.
examples.en: Because I had a bad experience, so I’m not willing to try again.

examples.cn: 因为我很喜欢游泳，所以我每周都去游泳池。
examples.pinyin: Yīnwèi wǒ hěn xǐhuān yóuyǒng, suǒyǐ wǒ měizhōu dū qù yóuyǒngchí.
examples.en: Because I really like swimming, therefore I go to the swimming pool every week.

examples.cn: 因为他考试考得不好，所以他感到非常失望。
examples.pinyin: Yīnwèi tā kǎoshì kǎo dé bù hǎo, suǒyǐ tā gǎndào fēicháng shīwàng.
examples.en: Because he didn't do well in the exam, so he felt very disappointed.

title: 不但...而且... (bùdàn... érqiě...) - Not only... but also...
short_explanation: Used to express two connected thoughts or facts.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese phrase '不但...而且...' (bùdàn... érqiě...) is a conjunction used to present two related points or facts. The structure '不但...而且...' means 'not only, but also' in English. It is used to explain a situation or event that doesn't just have one effect, circumstance, or quality, but multiple ones.

examples.cn: 他不但会说中文，而且还会写中文。
examples.pinyin: Tā bùdàn huì shuō zhōngwén, érqiě hái huì xiě zhōngwén.
examples.en: He can not only speak Chinese, but also write in Chinese.

examples.cn: 你的方案不但实用，而且还创新。
examples.pinyin: Nǐ de fāng'àn bùdàn shíyòng, érqiě hái chuàngxīn.
examples.en: Your plan is not only practical, but also innovative.

examples.cn: 这个城市不但文化底蕴丰富，而且经济发展迅速。
examples.pinyin: Zhègè chéngshì bùdàn wénhuà dǐyùn fēngfù, érqiě jīngjì fāzhǎn xùnsù.
examples.en: This city is not only rich in cultural heritage, but also has rapid economic development.

examples.cn: 我不但喜欢读书，而且喜欢看电影。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ bùdàn xǐhuān dúshū, érqiě xǐhuān kàn diànyǐng.
examples.en: I not only like reading, but also watching movies.

title: 虽然...但是... (suīrán... dànshì...) - Although/Though... But...
short_explanation: Used to present contrasting information or to express a concession.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese phrase '虽然...但是... (suīrán... dànshì...)' is a conjunction or a coordinating phrase used to present two contrastive ideas. The phrase '虽然' introduces a premise that could be an advantage, positive factor, or desired situation, while '但是' introduces a contrasting statement or reality that often undermines the premise initially presented. It is equivalent to the English phrase 'Although... But...'
formation: 虽然 + Statement 1,  但是 + Statement 2

examples.cn: 虽然外面正在下雨，但是他们还是决定出去跑步。
examples.pinyin: Suīrán wàimiàn zhèngzài xiàyǔ, dànshì tāmen háishì juédìng chūqù pǎobù.
examples.en: Although it's raining outside, they still decided to go for a run.

examples.cn: 虽然她很忙，但是她总是找时间去健身房。
examples.pinyin: Suīrán tā hěn máng, dànshì tā zǒng shì zhǎo shíjiān qù jiànshēnfáng.
examples.en: Although she's very busy, she always finds time to go to the gym.

examples.cn: 虽然他对音乐有热情，但是他决定选择医学作为他的职业。
examples.pinyin: Suīrán tā duì yīnyuè yǒu rèqíng, dànshì tā juédìng xuǎnzé yīxué zuòwéi tā de zhíyè.
examples.en: Although he has a passion for music, he decided to choose medicine as his profession.

examples.cn: 虽然我们尽力了，但是我们还是输了比赛。
examples.pinyin: Suīrán wǒmen jìnlìle, dànshì wǒmen háishì shūle bǐsài.
examples.en: Although we tried our best, we still lost the match.

title: 如果...的话 (rúguǒ... dehuà) - If...
short_explanation: It is used for hypothetical scenarios, equivalent to 'if...' in English.
long_explanation: In Mandarin Chinese, '如果...的话 (rúguǒ... dehuà)' is a conditional statement often used to introduce hypothetical situations or conditions. Much like the English 'if...', it sets up a premise that leads to a consequent statement or action. '如果' translates to 'if' and '的话' acts as a conditional marker, making the 'if' statement softer and less direct.
formation: 如果 + Condition + 的话, + Outcome

examples.cn: 如果你明天有空的话，我们可以一起去公园。
examples.pinyin: Rúguǒ nǐ míngtiān yǒu kòng dehuà, wǒmen kěyǐ yīqǐ qù gōngyuán.
examples.en: If you are free tomorrow, we can go to the park together.

examples.cn: 如果我赢了比赛的话，我会给你买一个礼物。
examples.pinyin: Rúguǒ wǒ yíng le bǐsài dehuà, wǒ huì gěi nǐ mǎi yīgè lǐwù.
examples.en: If I win the competition, I will buy you a gift.

examples.cn: 如果你不喜欢吃辣的话，可以试试这个菜。
examples.pinyin: Rúguǒ nǐ bù xǐhuan chī là dehuà, kěyǐ shìshì zhège cài.
examples.en: If you don't like spicy food, you can try this dish.

examples.cn: 如果你累了的话，我们可以休息一下。
examples.pinyin: Rúguǒ nǐ lèi le dehuà, wǒmen kěyǐ xiūxí yīxià.
examples.en: If you're tired, we can take a break.

title: 不过 (búguò) - However/But
short_explanation: Used to express contrast or bring up an exception to a situation.
long_explanation: '不过 (búguò)' is a conjunction used in Mandarin Chinese to mark a transition or contrast between two clauses. It can be translated as 'however', 'but', or 'yet' in English. This conjunction often introduces a sentence or a clause that provides additional, contrasting, or contradictory information to a previous statement.

examples.cn: 我本来想去公园玩。不过天气不好，所以我决定呆在家里。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ běnlái xiǎng qù gōngyuán wán. Búguò tiānqì bù hǎo, suǒyǐ wǒ juédìng dāi zài jiā lǐ.
examples.en: I originally wanted to go to the park. However, the weather is bad, so I decided to stay at home.

examples.cn: 他是个好人，不过有时候他的话语很尖酸。
examples.pinyin: Tā shì gè hǎo rén, búguò yǒushíhòu tā de huàyǔ hěn jiānsuān.
examples.en: He is a good person, however, sometimes his words are very sharp.

examples.cn: 我喜欢听音乐，不过我不喜欢唱歌。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ xǐhuan tīng yīnyuè, búguò wǒ bù xǐhuan chànggē.
examples.en: I like listening to music, but I don't like singing.

examples.cn: 这部电影看起来很有趣，不过我现在没有时间去看。
examples.pinyin: Zhè bù diànyǐng kàn qǐlai hěn yǒuqù, búguò wǒ xiànzài méiyǒu shíjiān qù kàn.
examples.en: This movie looks very interesting, however, I don't have time to watch it now.

title: 除了...以外 (chúle... yǐwài) - Apart from.../Besides...
short_explanation: Used to refer to exceptions or to add additional information.
long_explanation: '除了...以外 (chúle... yǐwài)' is a common Mandarin Chinese structure used to denote an exception to a general statement, or to introduce supplemental information. It is roughly equivalent to the English expressions 'apart from...', 'besides...', or 'in addition to...'.
formation: Subject + 除了 Noun/Verb Phrase 以外(, 还)+ Rest of the sentence

examples.cn: 除了英语以外，我还会说一点儿法语。
examples.pinyin: Chúle Yīngyǔ yǐwài, wǒ hái huì shuō yīdiǎnr Fǎyǔ.
examples.en: Apart from English, I can also speak a little French.

examples.cn: 除了我的家人以外，没有人知道我要去中国。
examples.pinyin: Chúle wǒ de jiārén yǐwài, méiyǒu rén zhīdào wǒ yào qù Zhōngguó.
examples.en: Apart from my family, no one knows that I'm going to China.

examples.cn: 除了游泳以外，她还喜欢打篮球。
examples.pinyin: Chúle yóuyǒng yǐwài, tā hái xǐhuan dǎ lánqiú.
examples.en: Besides swimming, she also likes to play basketball.

examples.cn: 除了热的食物以外，我还喜欢吃冷的点心。
examples.pinyin: Chúle rè de shíwù yǐwài, wǒ hái xǐhuān chī lěng de diǎnxīn.
examples.en: Apart from hot meals, I also like to eat cold snacks.

title: 又...又... (yòu... yòu...) - Both... and...
short_explanation: This construction is used to express that something or someone has two or more qualities or is doing two or more actions simultaneously.
long_explanation: '又...又...' (yòu...yòu...) in Mandarin Chinese is a structural pattern that is used to describe two or more characteristics, actions, or states that exist simultaneously. It is comparable to 'both...and...' in English. In this pattern, the two parts (represented by '...') can be either verbs, adjectives or even phrases, showing that both conditions apply.
formation: Subject + 又 + Verb/Adjective 1 + 又 + Verb/Adjective 2

examples.cn: 他又高又帅，真是让人羡慕。
examples.pinyin: Tā yòu gāo yòu shuài, zhēnshi ràng rén xiànmù.
examples.en: He is both tall and handsome, really enviable.

examples.cn: 这部电影又悲又喜，让人感动又让人开心。
examples.pinyin: Zhè bù diànyǐng yòu bēi yòu xǐ, ràng rén gǎndòng yòu ràng rén kāixīn.
examples.en: This movie is both sad and happy, it makes people feel moved and also makes them happy.

examples.cn: 她又会唱歌又会跳舞，非常有才华。
examples.pinyin: Tā yòu huì chànggē yòu huì tiàowǔ, fēicháng yǒu cáihuá.
examples.en: She can both sing and dance, she is very talented.

examples.cn: 这个城市又大又繁华，吸引了很多游客。
examples.pinyin: Zhège chéngshì yòu dà yòu fánhuá, xīyǐnle hěnduō yóukè.
examples.en: This city is both big and prosperous, attracting many tourists.

title: 都 (dōu) - All/Both
short_explanation: Used to show that something applies to every person or thing in a group.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese word '都 (dōu)' is often used to express 'all' or 'both' when referring to a group or set of things or people. It can be used in relation to quantity, time, and other contexts that involve inclusivity of a group. It typically follows the subject or the object of the sentence.

examples.cn: 我们都喜欢跳舞。
examples.pinyin: Wǒmen dōu xǐhuan tiàowǔ.
examples.en: We all like dancing.

examples.cn: 他们都是我的好朋友。
examples.pinyin: Tāmen dōu shì wǒ de hǎo péngyǒu.
examples.en: They are all my good friends.

examples.cn: 这些书我都读过。
examples.pinyin: Zhèxiē shū wǒ dōu dúguò.
examples.en: I have read all these books.

examples.cn: 咖啡和茶我都喜欢。
examples.pinyin: Kāfēi hé chá wǒ dōu xǐhuan.
examples.en: I like both coffee and tea.

title: 一边...一边... (yìbiān... yìbiān...) - Doing two actions simultaneously
short_explanation: This structure is used to describe doing two things at the same time.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese structure '一边...一边...' (yìbiān... yìbiān...) is used to express the simultaneous occurrence of two actions or events. This structure is equivalent to stating 'while doing one thing, also doing another thing' in English. It conveys the message that two activities are happening at the same time.
formation: Subject + 一边 + Action 1 + 一边 + Action 2

examples.cn: 她一边做饭一边看电视。
examples.pinyin: Tā yìbiān zuò fàn yìbiān kàn diànshì.
examples.en: She cooks while watching TV.

examples.cn: 我一边跑步一边听音乐。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ yìbiān pǎobù yìbiān tīng yīnyuè.
examples.en: I listen to music while running.

examples.cn: 他一边吃饭一边看报纸。
examples.pinyin: Tā yìbiān chī fàn yìbiān kàn bàozhǐ.
examples.en: He reads the newspaper while eating.

examples.cn: 我们一边走路一边聊天。
examples.pinyin: Wǒmen yìbiān zǒulù yìbiān liáotiān.
examples.en: We chat while walking.

title: 先...再... (xiān... zài...) - First... then...
short_explanation: This is used to express a sequence of actions in order of occurrence.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese construct '先...再...' is commonly used to express the idea of 'first...then...' This structure is used when you want to describe actions that happen in a specific order. '先 (xiān)' means 'first', and '再 (zài)' means 'then' or 'next'.
formation: 先 + Verb Phrase 1 + 再 + Verb Phrase 2

examples.cn: 我先去超市买东西，再回家做饭。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ xiān qù chāoshì mǎi dōngxi, zài huí jiā zuò fàn.
examples.en: I will go to the supermarket to buy things first, then go home to cook.

examples.cn: 你先完成作业，再看电视。
examples.pinyin: Nǐ xiān wánchéng zuòyè, zài kàn diànshì.
examples.en: First finish your homework, then watch TV.

examples.cn: 我们先吃饭，再去看电影。
examples.pinyin: Wǒmen xiān chīfàn, zài qù kàn diànyǐng.
examples.en: We will eat first, then go watch a movie.

examples.cn: 她先要参观博物馆，再去公园散步。
examples.pinyin: Tā xiān yào cānguān bówùguǎn, zài qù gōngyuán sànbù.
examples.en: She wants to visit the museum first, then go for a walk in the park.

title: 越...越... (yuè... yuè...) - The more... the more...
short_explanation: Used to indicate that one action or situation impacts another in a proportional way.
long_explanation: '越...越...' in Mandarin Chinese is a structure used to indicate that the degree of one event or action corresponds to the degree of another. In English, this structure is similar to 'the more..., the more...' meaning that as one thing increases or intensifies, so does the other.
formation: Subject + 越 + Adjective/Verb + 越 + Adjective/Verb

examples.cn: 我越看这部电影，我就越喜欢它。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ yuè kàn zhè bù diànyǐng, wǒ jiù yuè xǐhuan tā.
examples.en: The more I watch this movie, the more I like it.

examples.cn: 他越吃巧克力，他就越胖。
examples.pinyin: Tā yuè chī qiǎokèlì, tā jiù yuè pàng.
examples.en: The more he eats chocolate, the fatter he gets.

examples.cn: 孩子们越大，他们就越独立。
examples.pinyin: Háizimen yuè dà, tāmen jiù yuè dúlì.
examples.en: The bigger the children are, the more independent they become.

examples.cn: 你越早完成作业，你就可以越早去玩。
examples.pinyin: Nǐ yuè zǎo wánchéng zuòyè, nǐ jiù kěyǐ yuè zǎo qù wán.
examples.en: The sooner you finish your homework, the sooner you can go play.

title: 完 (wán) - Finish
short_explanation: Used as a verb complement to indicate the completion of an action.
long_explanation: The Mandarin Chinese word '完 (wán)' is often used as a verb complement to show that an action has been completed. It should be placed after a verb, meaning that the action of the verb is finished or completed. In English, it is often translated as 'finish' or 'complete'.

examples.cn: 我吃完饭了。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ chī wán fàn le.
examples.en: I have finished eating.

examples.cn: 他看完了这本书。
examples.pinyin: Tā kàn wán le zhè běn shū.
examples.en: He has finished reading this book.

examples.cn: 她写完作业后，就去睡觉了。
examples.pinyin: Tā xiě wán zuòyè hòu, jiù qù shuìjiào le.
examples.en: After she finished her homework, she went to sleep.

examples.cn: 我昨天看完了那部电影。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ zuótiān kàn wán le nà bù diànyǐng.
examples.en: I finished watching that movie yesterday.

title: 得 (de) - Structural particle indicating how an action is done
short_explanation: Used to indicate the manner or degree in which the action is performed.
long_explanation: In Mandarin Chinese, '得 (de)' is a structural particle used to illustrate how an action is performed or the degree to which it is executed. This particle is placed after a verb and before the description of the manner or the degree. It is equivalent to English expressions like 'how' or 'to what degree'.
formation: Subject + Verb + '得' + Description of manner/degree + Rest of the sentence

examples.cn: 她跑得非常快。
examples.pinyin: Tā pǎo de fēicháng kuài.
examples.en: She runs very fast.

examples.cn: 你说得对，我们应该更努力工作。
examples.pinyin: Nǐ shuō de duì, wǒmen yīnggāi gèng nǔlì gōngzuò.
examples.en: What you said is correct, we should work harder.

examples.cn: 他的中文写得很漂亮。
examples.pinyin: Tā de Zhōngwén xiě de hěn piàoliang.
examples.en: His Chinese writing is very beautiful.

examples.cn: 这个菜做得非常好吃。
examples.pinyin: Zhège cài zuò de fēicháng hǎochī.
examples.en: This dish is cooked very deliciously.
